definitions.definition: a plant that is grown in large quantities, especially as food

examples.text: Sugar cane is an important crop on the island.
What are the benefits of growing **GM crops**?
**food crops**
**crop yield/production**
to **grow/plant/harvest crops**
The crops are regularly sprayed with pesticides.
Crop rotation helps prevent soil erosion.
Crops are sprayed with highly toxic chemicals to prevent insect damage.
Fodder crops are used to feed livestock.
Isolated communities were extremely vulnerable if crops failed.
It takes three to five years for a new plantation to bear a crop.
Most of the farmers grow arable crops.
Rice is a staple crop for more than half of the world's population.
Rivers burst their banks and flooded standing crops.
Summer flash floods destroyed the crops.
to boost crop yields

definitions.definition: the amount of grain, fruit, etc. that is grown in one season

examples.text: a fall in this year’s coffee crop
Australia's wheat crop is likely to be lower than forecast this year.
We are looking forward to a **bumper crop** *(= a very large one)*.
We had a very good crop of apples last year.
a crop of carrots
a record crop was harvested

definitions.definition: a group of people who do something at the same time; a number of things that happen at the same time

examples.text: the current crop of trainees
She is really **the cream of the crop** *(= the best in her group)*.
a **crop of disasters/injuries**

definitions.definition: a short whip used by horse riders

examples.text: a riding crop
She has her hair cut in a short crop.

definitions.definition: hair that is short and thick
definitions.sensetop: a crop of dark, fair, etc. hair/curls

examples.text: He had a thick crop of black curly hair.

definitions.definition: a part of a bird’s throat that has the shape of a bag where food is stored before it passes into the stomach

wordOrigin: Old English, of Germanic origin; related to German Kropf. From Old English to the late 18th cent. there existed a sense ‘flower head, ear of corn’, giving rise to sense (1) and senses referring to the top of something.
